p.s: In my opinion Shakespeare is still very relevant but also irrelevant at the same time.
He himself as a person is still very relevant today but his work's relevance is just to a certain extent.
Shakespeare as a person is very relevant and a huge historical figure because he's benefitted so much to the englishEnglish language as a whole.
So many words he's made up are still being used to this day.
Without the influence of William Shakespeare the englishEnglish language as we know it today would be way poorer in diversity.
Even though many words of his aren't being used anymore he's benefitted quite a lot.
Even many quotes from Shakespeare's plays are being used as sayings today.
For example fight fire with fire or not everything that glitters is gold are such quotes being used today.
One can say that Shakespeare has enriched the englishEnglish by a lot.
On the other hands many people don't believe that a common peasant like Shakespeare would've been able to even come up with everything he's come up with.
Many believe that it's all been written by a nobleman under Shakespeare's name because being a poet wasn't really a well-suited confession at the time.
This sort of behaviour isn't something that young people should or could learn from in any way.
In my opinion Shakespeare as a person is a very big historical figure and should be teached in school even for young people cause he's still relevant up to this day as mentioned before.
The work of Shakespeare is a whole different thing though.
For most young people including me Shakespeare's work is very hard to understand.
It just gets annoying and doesn't really educate because most of the language is just so outdated and hard to understand.
The topics addressed in most of his work is still relevant today but nobody really benefits anyone if they're not able to understand it due to it'sits language.

I do believe though that simplified versions of Shakespeare's work should even get taught to younger people so they can evaluate their relevance today themselves and they don't have to worry about not understanding the core of it.
I even think that even the harer to understand original work of Shakespeare should be taught at school but only to those who want it.
In the higher classes students should be able to decide if they want to focus on englishEnglish literature for example or something else.
by giving this choice only those people who really want to read Shakespeare's work will be able to do so in class.
Even though it's hard to understand, the work of Shakespeare is still relevant to this day and it should be treated so.
Shakespeare may not have a relevance as huge for young young people as it had 100 years ago but he's still relevant to a certain extent.
This relevance will probably still be for a longtime but students, especially young students should be able to get introduced to him in a way lighter way than they are today.
